name.en: Chair of Public Economics and Policy

structural_unit_name.en: Chair of Public Economics and Policy

description.en: The main concepts of the new institutional economics which include transaction costs, relational contracts, principalagent relations and property rights are treated. The applying of these concepts to the studing of the main social economical institutions (market, contracts, firm, law, state) is surveyved.
description.et: Vaadeldakse uue institutsiooniökonoomika põhikontseptsioone, mis seostuvad transaktsioonikulude, suhtelepingute, esindussuhte ja käsutusõigustega. Käsitletakse nende kontseptsioonide rakendusi põhiliste  sotsiaal-majanduslike institutsioonide (turg, lepingud, ettevõte, õigus, riik) uurimisel.

objectives.en: Explain the role and formation of institutions in society and economy.
objectives.et: Selgitada majanduse ja ühiskonna institutsionaalset mitmekesisust ning institutsioonide majanduslikku rolli, näidata majandusteooria võimalusi turuväliste institutsioonide uurimisel.

learning_outcomes.en: To know main concepts and models of institutional economics, have knowledge to apply them in researching all spheres of society's life.
learning_outcomes.et: Tunda institutsiooniökonoomika põhikontseptsioone ja -mudeleid, osata neid rakendada kõigi ühiskonnaelu valdkondade uurimisel.

description.et: 4 short assignments for lecture time, each worth 5 points maximum, total 20 points. Mid-term test worth maximum 20 points; case-study max 18+5 points.
Seminar work maximum 37 points: including max 25 points for presentation and for participation 12 points (each of 6 seminars from the 9th to the 14th week is worth 2 points)

grade_evaluation.et: 60%  of current course work or with writing final test. In the second case for total result 30% of points achieved during the semester will be taken into account +70% from final test points achieved. In the second option at least 52 points in total are required for 'pass'-result.

3. Kasper, W., Streit, M. E. Institutional Economics. Social Order and Public Policy.The Locke Institute, Edward Elgar, 1998
4. North, D. C. Institutions, Institutional Change and Economic Performance, Cambridge University Press, 1990.
